It seems that the boy’s classmates were giving him a hard time about the fact that his father runs a company — as if it were something to be embarrassed by. lead_paragraph: ‘This is Not God’s Work’ Bill Gross: “Fifty years ago, the highest paid and most prestigious professions were that of a doctor or a 707 airline pilot who flew the “golden” route from Los Angeles to Honolulu. Today the yellow brick road begins on Wall Street or the City. Aside from supernova innovators such as Steve Jobs or Mark Zuckerberg, the money is made from securitizing things instead of booting and rebuilding America. . .. Almost a quarter of the 400 wealthiest people on Forbes annual richest list make their money from money, whereas only 8% could make that claim in its first issue in 1982, and probably close to 0% when I first read my economic primer in 1966. Having been part of this process and even a member of the rogue’s gallery itself, I know one thing for sure: This is not God’s work – it has the unmistakable odor of Mammon.” Pimco

lead_paragraph: Investors in Diamondback Partners, one of four hedge funds raided by federal authorities in November amid a widening investigation of suspected insider trading on Wall Street, have asked for more than $500 million back from the firm, according to the fund’s latest investor letter..The amount, totaling $534 million, represents around 9.4 percent of Diamondback’s total assets, according to the letter, defying expectations that the firm would experience enormous outflows after it was implicated in the investigation. lead_paragraph: My column this week describes a new strategy for improving the performance of government programs. In short, private investors — typically foundations — pay the costs of a new program in its early years, and the government later repays the investors, often with a bonus, as long as the program meets its goals. If it fails, taxpayers pay nothing.

abstract: Trust me, it’s easy to run up a thousand-dollar bill on your cellphone in a single trip if you don’t know the ins and outs.
snippet: Trust me, it’s easy to run up a thousand-dollar bill on your cellphone in a single trip if you don’t know the ins and outs.
lead_paragraph: I do a modest amount of international business travel, including Asia. I pretty much always have multiple projects in various stages of production, which typically means I can’t afford to be out of touch for much more than a few hours. (Also, I want to be available for family emergencies, like the time the TV went on the fritz.) I’ve put a lot of effort into figuring out tricks for being reachable by phone and e-mail without spending a fortune. Trust me, it’s easy to run up a thousand-dollar bill on your cellphone in a single trip if you don’t know the ins and outs. And not being in touch at all can be even more costly. Here are some of the lessons I’ve learned:

headline.main: Staying Connected Overseas (Cheaply)

abstract: With the bulk of its unsecured debt owed to publishers, the bookstore chain has a big hurdle to a fast exit from Chapter 11.
snippet: With the bulk of its unsecured debt owed to publishers, the bookstore chain has a big hurdle to a fast exit from Chapter 11.
lead_paragraph: That the Borders Group has filed a Chapter 11 petition is not so much news. Its fate will undoubtedly be blamed on e-books and Amazon.com, but big box retail companies like Borders, Barnes & Noble, Blockbuster and Circuit City long ago decided to compete solely on the basis of price, and they rise and fall on that basis alone. It seems to me that this is not so much about e-books as competition with a lower priced rival.

lead_paragraph: Rage Against the Money Machine Matt Taibbi is frustrated and angry at the lack of prosecutions stemming from the financial crisis: “The mental stumbling block, for most Americans, is that financial crimes don’t feel real; you don’t see the culprits waving guns in liquor stores or dragging coeds into bushes. But these frauds are worse than common robberies. They’re crimes of intellectual choice, made by people who are already rich and who have every conceivable social advantage, acting on a simple, cynical calculation: Let’s steal whatever we can, then dare the victims to find the juice to reclaim their money through a captive bureaucracy.” Rolling Stone

snippet: How did Time Inc. end up hiring an outsider — a transplant that did not take — when it once had the deepest bench in publishing?
lead_paragraph: Like most bad news, the departure of Jack Griffin — the chief executive of Time Inc. for less than six months — dropped at the end of the day, leaving the publishing community scratching its head and wondering how things had gone so wrong. No one, including Mr. Griffin, saw this one coming. He was at a board meeting of Next Issue Media until 4 p.m. on Thursday, and another executive at the meeting said it was clear that Mr. Griffin did not know he was about to be fired from the world’s largest magazine publisher.

headline.main: Time Inc.: The Anatomy of a Fiasco

abstract: Is Goldman the A.I.G. Villain?| In I.P.O.’s, Cheap Content Is King| Exchange Code Names
snippet: Is Goldman the A.I.G. Villain?| In I.P.O.’s, Cheap Content Is King| Exchange Code Names
lead_paragraph: Is Goldman Really to Blame? Some bloggers take issue with the view that Goldman Sachs was responsible for the 2008 collapse of the American International Group. “For me, it is difficult to see any malpractice from Goldman here. Goldman acted to protect itself, as it had every right to do. If A.I.G. did not want to have to accept Goldman’s valuations, it could have negotiated a different valuation procedure for the trades. Instead it left itself open to massive liquidity risk by agreeing to the collateral arrangements that it did. A.I.G. never considered the consequences were the underlyings to its trades to become illiquid, nor where it would find the collateral were the trades to go against them. For me that is by far the worst of the behavior seen here.” Deus Ex Macchiato

abstract: The hospital operator HCA is expected to price its inital public offering at about $30 a share.
snippet: The hospital operator HCA is expected to price its inital public offering at about $30 a share.
lead_paragraph: HCA, the hospital operator that was acquired by buyout firms in 2006, is seeking to price its initial public offering at as much as $30 a share when it begins its presentation to investors next week, people briefed on the matter said Friday. HCA has set a preliminary price of $27 to $30 for the stock sale, which is expected to be one of the biggest by a private equity-owned company in years. HCA was acquired in 2006 by a group led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Bain Capital and Merrill Lynch’s private equity arm. The company is one of the largest for-profit hospital operators in the United States, running 162 hospitals and 104 more surgery centers in the United States and Britain.

abstract: A large new study looks at whether elite colleges give their graduates an earnings advantage — and finds that, for most students, the answer is no.
snippet: A large new study looks at whether elite colleges give their graduates an earnings advantage — and finds that, for most students, the answer is no.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, two economists — Stacy Dale and Alan Krueger — published a research paper arguing that elite colleges did not seem to give most graduates an earnings boost. As you might expect, the paper received a ton of attention. Ms. Dale and Mr. Krueger have just finished a new version of the study — with vastly more and better data, covering people into their 40s and 50s, as well as looking at a set of more recent college graduates — and the new version comes to the same conclusion.

headline.main: Revisiting the Value of Elite Colleges

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced

abstract: Why keeping your brilliant business idea a secret may doom it to failure.
snippet: Why keeping your brilliant business idea a secret may doom it to failure.
lead_paragraph: You’ve heard of high-tech start-ups being in “stealth mode,” meaning they’re not telling anyone what they’re up to yet. It has a glamorous aura to it, conjuring up images of a brilliant project in the works that will soon be sprung upon the world, disrupting established players and leaving everyone scrambling to catch up. All smart companies with really great innovations keep those ideas hidden away until they’re ready to release them, lest competitors steal them. Look at Apple, which has perfected the art of secretiveness, to enormous profit. You can tell people about your great idea — but only if they sign one of those nondisclosure agreements you keep in your briefcase at all times. No exceptions!

headline.main: Got a Great Idea? Tell Everyone!

abstract: A surge in government hiring can’t be the reason the economy is struggling — because there has been no surge.
snippet: A surge in government hiring can’t be the reason the economy is struggling — because there has been no surge.
lead_paragraph: In my column this week, I mention that government employment and private sector employment have both fallen during the last two years. Over just the last year, private employment has risen — though more slowly than the population has been growing — while government employment has continued falling. These numbers make clear that a surge of government hiring can’t be the economy’s problem right now — because there has been no surge.

headline.main: Private Hiring and Government Layoffs

abstract: Yes, as recent numbers on jobless claims and home sales suggest.

lead_paragraph: You sometimes hear the claim that the economy cannot  recover before the housing market recovers. I think that’s wrong. Just because real estate led the economy into the recession does not mean it must lead the economy out. Other sectors can accomplish that. It’s more likely that the economy will need to recover — with unemployment falling and income rising — first and then housing will begin a very slow recovery.

lead_paragraph: One of the best things about my business is the variety of phone calls I get. My husband and I frequently look at each other at the office and say, “I wonder who’s going to call today.” It could be a business owner we met three years ago who is ready to talk about selling, or perhaps a referral from an interesting or unexpected source. There is, however, one particular type of phone call that I’ve come to dread — the ones from buyers who say they are looking for a business to buy as a passive investment.

headline.main: Can Owning a Business Ever Be a Passive Investment?

In the Weekend Business podcast, Catherine Rampell explains why: the turmoil in the Middle East has sent oil prices soaring. Investors fear that the unrest will spread to other countries, further disrupting production. In the United States, major cutbacks by state and local governments and threats of federal cutbacks are throwing more workers into the unemployment pool. Taken together, the uncertainty means businesses are unlikely to invest, let alone hire more workers.

lead_paragraph: The Oscars appear to have dodged a bullet. In a difficult year for the ABC telecast – two youthful and untested hosts and a group of top races with heavy favorites – early ratings from 56 markets were down only a smidge from last year. Among adults 18 to 49 in these markets, the 83rd Academy Awards posted a 14.5 rating, down from 14.8 last year, according to Nielsen. ABC won’t have national ratings, which will include information about millions of viewers, until about 3 p.m. Eastern time on Monday.
